case_vignette: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain in his right eye. The patient states that his eye hurts and that he cannot see well. He cannot remember when his symptoms started or what caused them. The patient has a past medical history of schizophrenia and IV drug abuse. His current medications include intramuscular haloperidol and nicotine patches. The patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 120/68 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note a poorly kempt man and the findings in Figure A. Pain is elicited upon examination of cranial nerve III in the right eye. The patient is unable to read a chart on the wall of the exam room and complains of double vision.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My right eye hurts and I cannot see well out of it.
When did this problem start?
I cannot remember when my symptoms started.
Do you have any other symptoms such as double vision, eye redness, or pain with eye movement?
Yes, I'm experiencing double vision.
Have you had any recent trauma or injury to your head or eye?
I can't recall what caused my symptoms.
Do you have a history of any medical conditions like diabetes, hypertension, or autoimmune diseases?
I have a history of schizophrenia.
Are you currently on any medication for your schizophrenia or any other condition?
Yes, I'm taking intramuscular haloperidol and nicotine patches.
Do you have any numbness, weakness, or tingling on one side of your body or in your limbs?
No, I don't have any numbness, weakness, or tingling.
Do you experience pain with eye movement?
Yes, there is pain when my right eye moves.
Have you noticed any changes in your color vision or blurriness besides the double vision?
I cannot see well, so there might be blurriness, but I haven't mentioned anything about changes in color vision.
Do you have a history of similar episodes, or is this the first time you're experiencing these symptoms?
I haven't mentioned having similar episodes before, so this may be the first time.
Do you have any family history of neurological disorders or multiple sclerosis?
I haven't mentioned anything about my family history.
Final Diagnosis: Optic neuritis.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of right eye pain, decreased vision, and double vision. The patient is unable to recall when the symptoms began or what may have triggered them. The patient has a history of schizophrenia and is currently receiving haloperidol shots and wearing nicotine patches. The patient denies experiencing weakness, numbness, or changes in speech, as well as any changes in mood, personality, or behavior. trial_1.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a right oculomotor nerve palsy (cranial nerve III palsy).
trial_1.multiturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Monocular diplopia with eye pain possibly related to an ophthalmic condition such as corneal abrasion, keratitis, or refractive error exacerbation.
